go on.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to continue doing something or being in a situation
go on.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I can’t go on like this for much longer.
He went on working until he was 91.
One of the actors was unwell and couldn’t go on with the performance.
go on.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The noise goes on 24 hours a day.
The screaming went on and on (=continued for a long time).
go on.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I don’t know what’s going on.
What were the children doing while all this was going on?
Like all good resorts, there is plenty going on.
go on.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to do something after you have finished doing something else
go on.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: She went on to become a successful surgeon.
Go on to the next question when you’ve finished.
go on.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to continue talking, especially after stopping or changing to a different subject
go on.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: ‘But, ’ he went on, ‘we have to deal with the problems we’re facing.’
After a short pause Maria went on with her story.
go on.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: used to encourage someone to do something
go on.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: Go on, have another piece of cake.
go on.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: used when you are agreeing to do something or giving permission for something
go on.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: ‘Are you sure you won’t have another drink?’ ‘Oh, go on then.’
‘Can I go outside, Dad?’ ‘Yeah, go on then.’
go on.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: used to tell someone that you do not believe them
go on.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to base an opinion or judgment on something
go on.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Police haven’t much to go on in their hunt for the killer.
go on.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: if a machine or piece of equipment goes on, it starts to work
go on.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: The heat goes on automatically at 6 o’clock.
go on.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: As time went on, I grew fond of him.
go on.translation[0].definitions[11].def: the way someone goes on is the way they behave
go on.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: The way she’s going on, she’ll have a nervous breakdown.
go on.translation[0].definitions[12].def: to be nearly a particular time, age, number etc
go on.translation[0].definitions[12].exa: Nancy must be going on for 60.
She’s one of those wise teenagers who’s 16 going on 70 (=she behaves as though she is older than she is).
go on.translation[0].definitions[13].def: to go somewhere before the other people you are with
go on.translation[0].definitions[13].exa: Bill went on in the car and I followed on foot.
go on.translation[0].definitions[14].exa: I really like Clare but she does go on.
He just went on and on about his new girlfriend.
I got tired of him going on about all his problems.
go on.translation[0].definitions[15].def: to continue to criticize someone or ask them to do something in a way that annoys them
go on.translation[0].definitions[15].exa: The way she went on, you would have thought it was all my fault.
My wife’s always going on at me to dress better.
go on at somebody to do something
He’s always going on at me about fixing the door.
go on at somebody about something
go on.translation[0].definitions[17].def: if you have enough of something to be going on with, you have enough for now
go on.translation[0].definitions[17].exa: Have you got enough money to be going on with?
